Award.AwardTitle: Access to Cooperative Education Programs and the Academic and Employment Returns by Race, Gender, and Discipline

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
A cooperative education program (co-op) in engineering is a partnership between an academic institution and an employer designed to engage students in practical engineering experience through rotations of full-time employment and course study. Co-op employment provides students with discipline-relevant professional experience and early entry into the engineering labor force while serving as a recruitment tool for co-op companies. While much is known about the value of cooperative education programs, relatively little is known about why there are different rates of participation by race/ethnicity and how recruitment and pre-screening practices influence the diversity of students who participate in co-op programs. The objectives of this research project are to identify factors that influence student access to cooperative education programs and to determine the educational and employment returns associated with participation. Data include comprehensive longitudinal academic student records from multiple institutions, as well as surveys and interviews of students from a large research-intensive institution. Research findings will lead to the development of strategies to further enhance co-op recruitment and engagement of engineering students from a broader range of backgrounds, interests, and experiences as a pathway to increase the overall diversity of the professional engineering labor force.

This research is supported by the Research in Engineering Education Program of the Engineering Education and Centers Division.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study examined the effects of participation in cooperative education programs (co-ops) on engineering undergraduate students' academic and employment outcomes. Co-ops are partnerships between an academic institution and an employer designed to engage students in discipline-relevant professional work experience through rotations of full-time employment and full-time traditional classroom study. In engineering, co-ops can serve as an important bridge between academic study and professional engineering practice, and previous studies highlight the positive academic and employment returns to participating in co-ops. However, most voluntary co-op programs select student participants based on academic achievement and an application and interview process, essentially selecting students who likely would have performed well in their academic study and in the job market. Thus, it is unclear to what extent participation in co-ops themselves, rather than the selection of higher-performing students to participate, drives the apparent returns.

To address the selection issue and provide more meaningful estimates of the returns to co-op participation, we used propensity score matching. We compared co-op students with non-co-op students who have matching demographic characteristics and academic achievement--students who also likely would have performed well in their academic study and in the job market. We found that co-op participants are more likely than their non-co-op peers to graduate in an engineering major and to have higher final grade point averages (GPAs). Co-op participants are also more likely than their non-co-op peers to obtain a job in the engineering field and to earn higher starting salaries post-graduation.

We also investigated whether the returns to co-op participation--higher final GPA, likelihood of graduating in engineering, likelihood of attaining a job in engineering upon graduation, and higher starting salary--vary by gender and race/ethnicity. Among women engineering undergraduate students, co-op participation helps increase the likelihood of graduation in engineering and their final GPA. Findings also indicate that underrepresented racially minoritized (URM) engineering undergraduate students--African American/Black and Hispanic/Latinx students--who participate in co-ops are more likely to earn higher starting salaries than similar URM students who did not participate in co-ops. Thus, we conclude that access to co-op opportunities can have a positive meaningful impact on students' academic and career trajectories.

Our finding that voluntary co-op participation has clear benefits suggests the importance of understanding access to such programs. To begin to answer questions with respect to access to voluntary co-op programs, we integrated administrative data from a research-intensive academic institution with data from our student interviews and surveys to examine who is most likely to participate and why they participate. Controlling for other factors, results indicate that women and men engineering undergraduate students participate in co-ops at similar rates, but that Asian and Hispanic/Latinx students are less likely to participate in co-ops than their White and African American/Black counterparts. Further, rates of participation by gender and race/ethnicity vary by engineering discipline. As to why students participate, they named five goals: (1) to gain work experience and job training, (2) to earn money, (3) to obtain a competitive edge in the job market, (4) to network, and (5) to explore potential careers. The factors that discourage students from participating in co-ops are (1) the increased time to graduation, (2) the potential to miss opportunities on campus, and (3) the possibility of losing connections with peers and their academic class cohort. These findings highlight potential areas for co-op programs to develop interventions to encourage more students to consider participating in co-ops in order to receive the positive returns they provide.

Research findings provide support for promoting co-ops as a potential strategy to help improve student academic and employment outcomes. Our results provide engineering colleges with valuable information about who participates in co-op programs and the associated academic and employment returns by gender and race/ethnicity. Since co-ops provide students with early access to employment, inclusion of a broader range of students into co-ops may be a viable pathway to promote a more diverse engineering labor force. Overall, our research findings have implications for enhancing student educational achievement and employment attainment, as well as in increasing the overall diversity of the engineering workforce.
